You open fire on the Rockmen, and like cowards the SSLG ship jumps away. Disappointing, but at least you'll be able to reap the rewards from this fight.

You try and convince the two to stop their arguing. They won't listen, so you divert your efforts to convincing them to go elsewhere. This works, and though the Outcasts paid you already, they're so impressed by you being able to end the conflict without any bloodshed they offer a second reward.
"Alright fine. How about this?"
"Aw, that's too bad." You cut comms and leave.
"You dare insult us? This is an excellent price for an outstanding drone!" The Smugglers raise their weapons, furious.
As you hail the refugee ship, a pirate ship jumps into the system... it was using the refugee ship as bait!
Upon closer inspection, you realize the ship under attack was a Rebel scout! It's too damaged to put up much of a fight.

choice.text: Destroy the ship and salvage it.

event.text: You strip the ship of anything useful and leave its crew to hope help arrives.

choice.text: Use the leverage you gained by saving their lives to convince them to delay the pursuing fleet.

event.text: Hopefully that will buy you more time to get to the next sector.
You were too late. A hull breach deprived the crew of oxygen during your fight with the pirate. You salvage what you can.
The pirate's victim quickly jumps away before you have a chance to speak to them.
"Thank you for the aid! I'm an arms dealer that usually only works with Rebels, but considering the circumstances I'll make an exception."
"Thank the heavens you showed up! We don't have much to offer as a reward, but our Engineer should be proficient enough to patch your ship up a bit after that nasty fight."
"That's an excellent name! Thank you for your assistance."
The pirates have a brief discussion about your suggestion. "Perfect, this will be great! Thank you for your assistance, strange Federation ship. Here is some pay."
"That's uh... well thanks for trying, but I'm not really sure that's what we're looking for."
"That's an excellent name! Thank you for your assistance."
The pirates have a brief discussion about your suggestion. "Perfect, this will be great! Thank you for your assistance, strange Federation ship. Here is some pay."
"Dear god, that is a horrible name. Please never speak to us again."
Somehow, the pirates seem to like your suggestion. They like it so much in fact that they pay you scrap so long as you promise never to insult them with your horrible suggestions ever again.
The slavers bring over an unusually pristine slave, void of any restraints. As soon as the slavers return to their ship, the "slave" reveals a hidden blaster and turns on your crew! It was a trick!
The slavers bring out a prisoner in heavy shackles, and throw them aboard. The slaver captain hails you, and jumps away.
The ship remains completely unresponsive. You aren't sure if there's any life left on the ship.
Confident the former crew is dead, you start scrapping the outer hull. However, mid-way through the process the weapons mysteriously come online, and you can hear lethargic shuffling inside the ship.

To your surprise, your hail is answered almost immediately. Instead of comprehensible speech however, the response is garbled and mixed with static. Next thing you know, the ship's weapons come online and attack you!
You try to explain to the Engi that the "production amplifiers" are drugs, but they don't understand. The Zoltan grows impatient.

choice.text: Aid the Zoltan in arresting the Engi.

event.text: You quickly explain the Zoltan that you intend to help. "Fine, we will accept your assistance. But do not kill the Engi. This is a peaceful operation."
The Zoltan huff when you position your ship between them and the Engi. "You're aiding these criminals? Fine, then expect no mercy."

At first you aren't sure if the Engi understand, but they slowly begin to realize. You explain to the Zoltan the misunderstanding and the Engi transfer the drugs over to the Zoltans. Satisfied, the Zoltan ship jumps away. The Engi offer you some droneparts in thanks.
They appear to be filled with military supplies! You take everything you can use and jettison the rest.
The cargo was primarily consumer goods and clothing, nothing particularly useful. You manage to collect some scrap.

Once you bring the cargo onto your ship, a pirate bursts out of one of the crates saying, "Ugh... I was getting cramped in there. Oh, yeah! Prepare to die!" Immediately after this battle-cry your ship is filled with the sound of crates breaking open...
You bring the cargo aboard. Before you have a chance to open them a pirate ship appears out of hiding and charges. At the same time, the crates fly open. Intruders aboard the ship!
The cargo appears to contain nothing of much interest. You salvage some scrap from the destroyed ship.
You are able to breach the protective barrier and scan the cargo. It appears to be filled with military supplies! You take everything you can use.
You pick up faint life signatures inside the cargo. The life forms appear to be armed. This looks like a planned pirate ambush.

choice.text: Destroy the crates to prevent another ship from falling victim.

event.text: You fire on the crates, breaking them open and scattering the pirates into empty space. A pirate ship appears out of nowhere with a message, "You will pay for that!"

choice.text: Leave it alone and prepare to jump.

event.text: It would be stupid to try anything.
Three golden 7s flash on the screen, followed by loud fanfare and confetti. The machine exclaims in a loud voice, "CONGRATULATIONS! You lost!"
Three golden 7s flash on the screen, followed by loud fanfare and confetti. The machine exclaims in a loud voice, "CONGRATULATIONS! You lost!"
Three golden 7s flash on the screen, followed by loud fanfare and confetti. The machine exclaims in a loud voice, "CONGRATULATIONS! You lost!"
Three golden 7s flash on the screen, followed by loud fanfare and confetti. The machine exclaims in a loud voice, "CONGRATULATIONS! You lost!"
A low buzz emits from the machine and a drawer opens up, spitting out more scrap. It's rather anticlimactic, but you aren't complaining.

Your crew tells the Rebels about the role that they have played in the instability of the human governments. If the Rebels win, the struggles are not over, but the Federation will have to change for the better anyway. The Rebels are swayed by your crew's persuasiveness. One of the humans decides to dedicate themself to your cause!

Your crew talks about the amount of death that the conflict between the Rebels and the Federation has caused - and how the Federation is still committed to the safety and well being of all humans. The Rebels are swayed by your crew's persuasiveness. A combat medic seems to agree with your goals and aligns with you!

Your crew talks of how the Rebels have damaged the infrastructure of human societies in their fight, and how life has gotten worse, not better since the start of the war. The Rebels are swayed by your crew's persuasiveness. While they seem hesitant about following you to the end, they give you a small tribute for sparing them and talking to them instead of engaging in violence.

Your crew tries to talk about the danger that the Rebels pose to all of the species of the galaxy. The Rebel trainees are incensed with your crew's attempt to sway them away from their cause! The trainees form a small mob and chase you back to the ship. Some careless upstarts break into your ship, thinking they can take you.

Your crew try to talk about the damage that the war is doing to the galaxy, but the officers in charge of the training approach with weapons drawn, chasing you back to the ship. Two well trained soldiers break into your ship, it looks like you'll have to fend off an attack!

The talk goes poorly. Every argument your crew tries to make is rudely interrupted by the audience. The trainees grab weapons and begin to fire them - as the crew makes their way back to the ship, one of the trainees lobs an incendiary bomb at your ship!
Your improved Sensors are able to remotely access and download the public radar station's local map data.
The automated ship must be remotely connected to the station; as soon as you attempt to log on, the ship activates and charges you.
The ship patrols wide around the area, successfully approaching the station while avoiding detection.
Before you can get close enough to scan the station, the automated ship detects you and moves in to attack!
The station was either abandoned or stripped clean. It seems to have lain unused for quite some time. You find nothing useful.
The station was apparently designed to outfit Rebel ships with Drone Systems. You find a functioning Schematic.
The station is a storage site for military grade weapons. You find one that can be easily attached to the ship.
The station is a storage site for various resources. You salvage everything possible.
Your combat drone attacks the automated ship and then retreats, luring it away. You quickly move up to the radar station to access it.
Your combat drone repeatedly fires at the automated ship. It can't break through its shields, but is at least enough of a distraction to allow you to access the radar station.
Before your drone has a chance to attack, the automated ship activates and shoots it down. It then detects your ship and moves in on your position.
You successfully hack into their system and transmit false information about your location. That should hold off the fleet for at least a little while.
The firewalls prove too difficult to bypass. As you are about to disconnect, you stumble across unprotected information about the surrounding beacons. Your map is updated.
You are unable to penetrate the computer's defenses. You give up and return to the ship.
As you attempt to hack in, you set off a hidden alarm system. It seems that now the Rebels must surely be aware of your position! You hasten back to the ship to jump away.
You are able to pull all of the ship's data about this sector. Your map has been updated.
You accidentally reactivate the ship's AI. Its weapons immediately go online; prepare for a fight!
Your improved Sensors indicate that it's safe to hack into the drone. You upload its map data to your navigation system and strip the ship of useful materials.
Your improved Sensors indicate the ship is on standby, ready to activate at a moment's notice. Will you still attempt to access the ship's data?
You leave the ship alone and prepare to jump.

Your crewmember checks their intentions for a few seconds, but is unable to find anything suggesting that they would be hostile. You let the former Rebel join your crew, and prepare to fight the Rebel ship off.
It takes almost no time for your crewmember to determine that the Rebel in question is aiming to trick you. Though they're easily taken care off, you still have the other Rebels to deal with.
Your fearless crew easily overcome the intruder, but the Rebel ship still needs to be dealt with.
Attempting to deal with attacks from inside and out is never easy!
He offers to lead you to a secret cache of scrap nearby if you let him join your crew.

choice.text: Reluctantly accept his proposal and fight the Rebel ship.
Reject him outright and execute him on the spot.

event.text: The dishonorable Rebel has deceived you. He damages your engines and steals your flight data before teleporting away. The fleet will be able to track you with ease. If they can't kill you now that is!
Your new crew-member smiles, then reveals a small remote trigger in the palm of his hand. Explosions rocket around the ship as more intruders teleport aboard!
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
The Rebel makes to take his assigned station, then suddenly turns and eviscerates the nearest crew-member. Red Alert!

removeCrew.text: The eviscerated crewmember's clone launches out of the Clone Bay, eager to seek revenge.

event.text: The dishonorable Rebel has deceived you. He damages your ship and steals ship information before teleporting away. The fleet will be able to track you with ease. If they can't kill you now, that is!
Your new crew-member smiles, then reveals a small remote trigger in the palm of his hand. Explosions rocket around the ship as more intruders teleport aboard!
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
Relieved and light-headed, your new crewmember gets to work as the Rebel ship attacks.
The Rebel makes to take his assigned station, then suddenly turns and eviscerates the nearest crew-member. Red Alert!

removeCrew.text: The eviscerated crewmember's clone launches out of the Clone Bay, eager to seek revenge.

beaconType.unvisitedTooltip: Advertised location of a scrap stash given by a Rebel defector.

event.text: Arriving at the specified coordinates you find a sizable stash of useful materials.

beaconType.unvisitedTooltip: Advertised location of a scrap stash given by a Rebel defector.

event.text: You arrive at the location of the hoard, but discover that it was not quite as large as advertised.

A suspicious amount of time passes without response from your crew. You're about to call them when a group of security guards come out onto the stage. Your heart drops when you see the bruised body of your crew member with them. They whisper something to the politician, who then says, "It appears this scum has attempted to take my life with a simple hand held laser! The Federation cannot see that a little gun will not stop the Rebellion!" The guards drop your crew onto the floor, and the politician swiftly draws an old Earth revolver and shoots them three times in the head. You quickly hurry out of the stadium before they can catch any more of you.

removeCrew.text: Luckily, by the time you've returned to the ship your crew is already waiting in the Clone Bay room, pouting about their failure and public execution.

event.text: A long time goes by, and you begin to fear the worse. Suddenly, you hear shouts and even screaming and your crew member comes charging back through the crowd, followed by a set of guards. You run back to the ship, the guards following in pursuit.

A few minutes after you sent your crew away, a loud bang echoes across the stadium. The politician's eyes go wide in surprise and they flop off the stage into the crowd. The entire place erupts into total chaos, civilians running in every direction. Your crew member comes rushing back, and you head back to the ship as fast as possible. With all the chaos you've caused, the Rebels are going to need to spend a lot of time on damage control. You doubt the Fleet will be concerned with following you for a while.
Looks like most of the trash is just scrap, except for a few fuel cells that must have been discarded on accident.
Most of the stuff is worthless, save for what looks to be a weapon! It's old and rusty, but a gun is a gun, and you aren't complaining!
Looks like all the trash field has to offer is some measly scrap. Nevertheless, it's still something.
As it turns out, the settlement's defenses are a lot weaker than you first expected. They barely make an effort to fight back - instead handing over some supplies.
As it turns out, the settlement's defenses are a lot weaker than you first expected. They barely make an effort to fight back - instead handing over some supplies.
In response to your attack approach, the settlement has dispatched a ship to retaliate!
The settlement ignores your repeated hails. You suppose that's a sign not to linger any longer.
It appears the settlement is low on resources, having been forgotten thanks to their excellent camouflage. They offer to trade.
The settlement is friendlier than you expected. They promise to help with the Rebel fleet once they pass through this stretch of space.
You send your crew in, but after a few minutes of work, it's already clear why the leeches are having so much trouble with it. Unable to move any of the rubble, you leave, dejected.

You send your crew in, and for a while, it seems like nothing you do will move the rubble. However, just before you're about to leave, one of your crew manages to unblock a hallway, narrowly avoiding being crushed by the resulting avalanche of rubble. Satisfied, and not wanting to push your luck, you collect your payment from the station's management, then set off.
The ship being largely intact is a lucrative bounty of scrap and resources. You haul the bounty back to your ship with absolutely no resistance.
The ship being largely intact is a lucrative bounty of scrap and resources. As you scrap the ship, you discover a working drone schematic in the cargo bay.

You begin the transfer of the information. You watch as the data loads. Most of it is random junk, such as a recipe for fish shaped ethyl benzene cake and an article on the importance of honesty. At last, you see the map data downloading. You thank the Separatist, who nods, and jumps away once the transfer is complete.

You begin the transfer of the information. You watch as the data loads. Most of it is random junk, such as a recipe for fish shaped ethyl benzene cake and an article on the importance of honesty. However before the map data begins to download, an error occurs, and your computer shuts down. You wait but it stays offline, and you realize you've been tricked! The Separatist ship raises its weapons and moves in to attack!

"Yes, you are of peak physical condition. Satisfaction 98%. I can work out the last 2%. Thank you friend. Accept this gift as gratitude." He morphs into an exact copy of you and beams off the ship, leaving behind some droneparts.
"Your body is ugly. I do not wish to take this form. Goodbye." He beams off of the ship.

The basketball game between the two Engi teams is certainly a novelty. Their robotic movements and precise aim make for an unusual experience. The Separatist team clearly has more practice and skill. The result is a massive blowout, with the Separatists winning. As the losers, the Harmony team surrenders.
		
"Fortuitous result. We have won, the -Harmony- team must now attempt to assimilate into the Separatist [community]. As an appreciation for [your] time, you may take a -reward- from their stores."

The basketball game between the two Engi teams is certainly a novelty. Their robotic movements and precise aim make for an unusual experience. However, both sides seem to have fun. The Separatist team's experience gives them a leg up, and they manage to outscore their opponents by a handful of points.
		
"Fortuitous result. We have won, the -Harmony- team must now attempt to assimilate into the Separatist [community]. As an appreciation for [your] time, you may take a -reward- from their stores."

The basketball game between the two Engi teams is certainly a novelty. Their robotic movements and precise aim make for an unusual experience. However, both sides seem to have fun. The two teams end up neck-and-neck, and end up on a tie.
		
"No winner. It seems we will just go our separate ways. We appreciate your attempt to help us." They give you a few droneparts for your time.

The basketball game between the two Engi teams is certainly a novelty. Their robotic movements and precise aim make for an unusual experience. However, both sides seem to have fun. The Harmony team somehow pulls an underdog victory, meaning that the Separatists surrender.
		
"This = optimal. The Separatists have: surrendered nonviolently. Your advice = appreciated. This = ...a strange..." The Engi trails off. Is that a trace of melancholy in its voice?

You hear a fumbling noise and the camera turns on, revealing the captain of the ship is not a regular Engi, but a Separatist. They quickly turn it back off but the damage has already been done. "Look look, no -need- to do anything brash. We'll give you back [half] of what you paid us, and we don't -have- to fight. Fair?"
The arm unfolds once again and deposits half of what you had paid them. You notice they rounded down in their favor, but it's too late to complain as they hastily jump away.
The Separatist pleads for you to spare them, but you have no intentions on letting them live.
The camera feed flickers on, revealing a smug Separatist captain. "Sorry, but it [appears] you have been deceived. By me. I am very -smart- and clever. Ha ha. There is no [reward], by the way."
"Wait, what are -you- doing? No, no, stop. Wait. This is a [bad] idea!"

choice.text: Accept that you have been tricked.

event.text: The Separatist seems surprised that you have chosen not to fight back. You end the call and ignore the ship.
"Your donation is appreciated, Captain. I'll be honest. We are no -Harmony- ship. This ship is now under control of the Separatists. Still, we [thank] you. Please accept this gift."
"Wow. [You're] a real jerk, aren't you? What am I supposed [to] do now?" The Separatist ends the communication in a huff.
"You've destroyed my [property]. I -will- have my revenge."
"Since I now [have] no ship to house me, I will be forced to [join] yours."

Your Engi is sent down to the planet, where they successfully manage to find the source of the virus and purge it from some of the Separatist's systems. Once they're sure of how to do it on their own, they give your Engi a gift to bring back to the ship.

Your Engi attempts to debug the Separatists, but only ends up catching the virus themselves. It slowly erodes at the code that causes it to maintain a solid shape and evaporates as its nanobots scatter. The Separatists send their condolences but have nothing else to say.

removeCrew.text: You aren't sure if a virtual infection will carry over the Clone Bay, and attempt to revive your crew. Unfortunately the clone appears to be suffering many glitches and cannot keep a constant form. You put them out of their misery and delete their data from the clone bank.

event.text: Your Engi is sent down to the planet, where they successfully manage to find the source of the virus and purge it from some of the Separatist's systems. Once they're sure of how to do it on their own, they give your Engi a gift to bring back to the ship.

Your Engi attempts to debug the Separatists, but only ends up catching the virus themselves. It slowly erodes at the code that causes it to maintain a solid shape and evaporates as its nanobots scatter. The Separatists send their condolences but have nothing else to say.

removeCrew.text: You aren't sure if a virtual infection will carry over the Clone Bay, and attempt to revive your crew. Unfortunately the clone appears to be suffering many glitches and cannot keep a constant form. You put them out of their misery and delete their data from the clone bank.

event.text: Amid the interior of the ship are the corpses of several dozen spiders. In the helm sits the injured but alive captain. With his ship destroyed, he offers to join your crew.
Surprisingly, there's no spiders aboard the wreckage. You scrap the exterior of the ship.
As you should have expected, the ship is teeming with spiders. You manage to pull your crew back in time but the horde of spiders cannot be stopped.

As you should have expected, the ship is teeming with spiders. You order the crew back but it's too late, one of them falls victim to the swarm. You swiftly detach from the wreck before the spiders can get aboard.

removeCrew.text: Your crew has already been cloned, now with a deep sense of arachnophobia.

event.text: Scans of the wreckage show it is teeming with spiders. You decide it is best to ignore the ship.
You quickly scan the ship for lifeforms. Luckily, it appears no living creatures, including spiders, remain. You safely scrap the hull.
Your crewmember claims the wreckage is teeming with spiders. You decide it is best to ignore the ship.
Your crewmember seeks any potential lifeforms. Luckily, it appears no living creatures, including spiders, remain. You safely scrap the hull.

Your crew board the vessel, but are quickly stormed by spiders! They retreat back to the ship, but one of them doesn't make it. You watch as the spiders drag away their flailing body as you undock, unable to help. The Shells apologize for your loss and offer a piddly amount of scrap to "compensate".

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crew has already been cloned, but now with a deep-seeded sense of arachnophobia.

event.text: Fortunately for your crew, most of the spiders are sleeping. They step quietly through the halls until they grab one of the hatchlings and run back to the ship.
The Shells thank you for your help. "Thhhis will help our research greatly. Thhe first step to preventing thhhis infestation from spreading is to understand what makes thhhese spiders tick!"
"Thank you... this will help the Brood greatly!" Their weapons come online, a sure sign that this was a trap!
As you run to exit the yacht you are spotted by several pirates. You make it back to your ship in time, but a Brood vessel is in hot pursuit!
As you're about to leave, you receive another message. "Oh, don't be stingy! Come back here, dearie..." The Brood ship arms its weapons.
You don't do business with pirates.

Fortunately, Madrock's shuttle appears to still be in fairly good condition. You swoop in and retrieve him before jumping away. Madrock seems content to let you salvage his shuttle for what little it's worth.

You initially can't find Madrock's shuttle, but soon spot it plunging towards the nearby star. Seems its engines must have been struck by a particularly nasty solar flare during your earlier fight. You should still be able to swoop in and save him, but it may be risky.

You send your ship at full speed towards Madrock's shuttle. You're able to retrieve it just in time, but you're forced to take the full brunt of a solar flare just as you're leaving, leaving your ship in considerable disarray. The shuttle should make for good salvage later.

choice.text: (Adv. Shields) Your shields should be able to protect you from the solar flares... mostly.

event.text: You send your ship at full speed towards Madrock's shuttle. Though you manage to retrieve it in time, your ship is hit by a solar flare just as you're preparing to leave. Though your shields absorbed some of the impact, the it still leaves its mark on your ship. Once Madrock is aboard, you scrap his shuttle.

choice.text: (Adv. Engines) Quickly move in and save him.

event.text: Your powerful engines let you effortlessly swoop in towards the star, retrieve Madrock's shuttle, and get away before the next solar flare hits your ship. Once Madrock is aboard, you scrap his shuttle.
The nebula makes it difficult to get a lock on his life readings, but you manage to lock your teleporter onto him and safely retrieve him before it's too late.

choice.text: Leave him to his fate, it's too risky to save him.

event.text: "Combat unfavorable. Accept this -offer- and leave."
"Combat unfavorable. Accept this -offer- and leave."

"I have SINNED! I... used the restroom... and I was out of toilet paper... and I had a holy script nearby and... OH GOD! I'm a MONSTER! How could you make me relive my crimes? You are cruel! Too cruel for this world! First I will kill you, then myself!"

"I have SINNED! I... used the restroom... and I was out of toilet paper... and I had a holy script nearby and... OH GOD! I'm a MONSTER! Oh please, allow me to redeem myself! In any way I can, perhaps there are favors I can serve to find my way to heaven once more!"
"I have changed my mind! I no longer wish to die! I shall redeem myself by killing you instead!"
"Oh thank you good captain! Only in death shall I find redemption!"
Your human sings a gospel song. "When the rock cries out, no hiding place!" It absolutely brings the house down, with all the rockmen in the audience clapping along.
Your human pulls out an acoustic guitar and sings a country song. The rocks seem intrigued by the performance and clap politely.
Your human sings a song from the punk genre. The crowd doesn't seem into it at all, many looking like they can't wait for it to be over.
Your human has a little bit of classical music training, and plays on the piano. The Rocks seem to appreciate it, but it doesn't leave much of an impression on them.
The Separatist pulls from some Rockman classics, remixing and mashing them up on the spot. The Rockmen are intrigued by this concept and they seem to love it.
Your Separatist tries some freestyle nerdcore rap. The sound of the audience is a low murmur as they try and fail to digest what has just happened in front of them.
Your Separatist performs a highly abstract psychedelic piece. The audience seems uncertain what to feel. The judges discuss it animatedly, all pretending to understand what it was about.
While attempting to rob the temple, you are stopped by a Rock vessel, who immediately attacks!
Inside the temple you find some supplies and a Crystal weapon.
You find what appears to be pieces of a derelict Crystal station. Before you have a chance to dock, a few asteroids get past your shields and partially damage your engines. You'll have to pull out!
You find a pirate ship, damaged and abandoned. You salvage what you can and move on.
You find the decaying remains of a derelict Crystalline station. There's a weird sense of deja vu, and in the corner is a stasis pod and a Crystal weapon.
It looks like a massive asteroid is in a direct collision course with the station! You have to pull your crew out but they want to grab what they can first. What do they take?

choice.text: Take the weapon and any spare resources.

event.text: Your crew grabs what they can and returns to the ship before the asteroid hits. You take a look at what you've recovered once you move clear of the asteroid field.
Your crew drags the pod back to your ship before the asteroid smashes into the station, shattering through the crystal coating.

You're able to activate the stasis chamber once again and find the Crystal inside still alive. They're confused and wondering what year it is, so you give them a very simple explanation as to your current situation and hurry to leave the asteroid field.
You find the decaying remains of a derelict Crystalline station. There's a weird sense of deja vu, and in the corner is a stasis pod and a Crystal weapon.
It looks like a massive asteroid is in a direct collision course with the station! You have to pull your crew out but they want to grab what they can first. What do they take?

choice.text: Take the weapon and any spare resources.

event.text: Your crew grabs what they can and returns to the ship before the asteroid hits. You take a look at what you've recovered once you move clear of the asteroid field.
Your crew drags the pod back to your ship before the asteroid smashes into the station, shattering through the crystal coating.

You're able to activate the stasis chamber once again and find the Crystal inside still alive. They're confused and wondering what year it is, so you give them a very simple explanation as to your current situation and hurry to leave the asteroid field.
You salvage what you can from the ship. No one bothers you during the operation.
A Rock patrol ship jumps in while you are salvaging the ship. They message you, "Filthy pirates! Prepare to die!" You doubt explaining your mission will convince them of your need.
The Rock people are not known for setting traps but you hasten to leave anyway.
The Rock people are not known for setting traps but you hasten to leave anyway.

Before you have a chance to leave, a Rock patrol ship arrives and you intercept their comm chatter, "...appears we've finally found them. Their killing spree ends now!" Before you can plead your innocence they move in to attack.
You salvage what you can from the ship. No lifeforms or ships are detected nearby.
You begin the salvage operation but before long your crew warns you of an approaching ship. You hasten to leave before they get within firing range.
You salvage what you can from the ship. No lifeforms or ships are detected nearby.
You begin the salvage operation but before long your ship's sensors warns you of another approaching ship. You hasten to leave before they get within firing range.

The Mantis craft are both too busy slaughtering one another to notice you. Eventually the smaller ship gets the upper hand, but they must have blown a fuse in the assault and their weapons system is inoperable. Now is the time to attack!

The Mantis craft may have their differences, but when it comes to you they are of one mind. The smaller ship suffers a power failure as it moves to engage, but the larger one lets off a volley of fire and moves in to attack!
Your promises gain their attention and they agree to serve with you, for a while.
They seem tempted by your offer, but decide they can't risk being lied to again. They close frequencies and jump away.
They seem tempted by your offer, but decide they can't risk being lied to again. They close frequencies and jump away.
Your crewmember dons a space suit and exits the airlock. They make quick work of the basic device and return inside to relief all round. The mine makes good scrap pickings too.
Your crewmember dons a space suit and exits the airlock. When they open up the mine housing, though, they panic. The red wire or the blue?! 3... 2... 1...

choice.text: (Elite Crew) Send your elite to defuse the bomb.

event.text: Your Elite doesn't hesitate. They pull off a second panel in the back, and cut the newly revealed green wire. Miraculously, the bomb deactivates!
You open your eyes and everything is still where it was a moment ago. You did it!

The weapon detonates. Everything goes dark, the bridge illuminated by flames pouring from the hull, your bomb disposal volunteer spinning off toward a nearby sun. You put out the fires and prepare to move on.

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them. Sheepish and apologetic, they rejoin the crew.

event.text: Apparently the Rock Captain was more annoyed than you thought, they shut off all communication and turn on you, the 'slime balls' defender.
With much grumbling, the Rock Captain agrees to pay the price.

A massive explosion emanates from the Rock Ship, shattering its hull and sending debris on an unavoidable collision course to your ship. Seems like that reactor upgrade was poorly done after all, and the Slugs took the opportunity to jump away.
The Slugs offer their thanks for your help, and jump away. Their true appreciation is questionable, but at least you can get back to your mission.
The Slug Captain offers a free reactor upgrade for your help. It never hurts to get a little power boost!
The Slug Captain, thankful for your help, offers a reactor upgrade for your ship... for a 'fair' price.
You let their team on board and after a short time they finish their work.
You break communications and prepare to move on.
"Hahahah! Like hell I'd take the adviccce of a Federation captain, essspecccially when he tellss me I should just let myssself get ssscammed out of my money!" The Slug ship immediately turns hostile!
You're pretty certain you hear the Slugs say some nasty things about your mother under their breath, but they do reluctantly accept the Rockman's new price.

A massive explosion emanates from the Rock Ship, shattering its hull and sending debris on an unavoidable collision course to your ship. Seems like that reactor upgrade was poorly done after all, and the Slugs took the opportunity to jump away.
The Rock captain grumbles then jumps away without another word. You know Rockmen tend to be ungrateful as a culture, but this is just plain rude.
The Rock captain seems rather ungrateful for your assistance, and still bent out of shape by his unsatisfactory reactor upgrades. "And what am I supposed to do about this crapjob upgrade?"

With some scrap of your own, you work on the Rockman's reactor to spruce it up. "Still a cruddy job, but at least you aren't as bad as those sludge gushers." It's a very reluctant compliment, but you can tell the Rockman appreciates it because he returns carrying a gift!

You aren't sure what reaction you expected from this response, but the abrupt laughter from the Rock captain surprises you. "I like your style." Brief, but a compliment from a Rockman is nothing to scoff at. Especially since it's followed by a small gift as a "thank you" for helping them.

Most of the Rockmen are too panicked and flee as you approach. A few of the more sensible individuals stop to hear you out. You offer to transport as many of them as you can carry, an offer which most of them refuse. One young Rockman however accepts, even going so far as to join your crew.
As you approach, a pirate ship locks onto you and fires a few shots across your hull. You're forced to pull away, but the pirates follow in pursuit!
The only place safe for you to land is near empty patch of land that was once a residential complex. Now reduced to rubble, you salvage what little hasn't already been taken.
The Rock Enforcers are too busy dealing with the pirates to notice you. You swoop in and collect as much as you can.
It seems one of the Elite rock vessels trying to fend off the pirates has noticed you. You're chased by the ship, and it seems a fight is unavoidable.
With the help of your Cloaking, you're able to retrieve a hefty amount of wreckage without any of the Rock Enforcers noticing you. Once you can't collect any more scrap, you make a quick escape.
With the help of your Cloaking, you're able to retrieve a hefty amount of wreckage without any of the Rock Enforcers noticing you. Once you can't collect any more scrap, you make a quick escape.
You try to get closer to salvage the wreckage, but your Cloaking gives out just before an elite Rock ship turns to where you are. At this point, a fight is inevitable.
Things, in the end, do not go well. The enemy succeeds in flanking your team and they're forced to retreat to the ship.
The staff and authorities subdue the last of the renegade students; prison transport ships are already in orbit.

The fight goes poorly, and your team eventually finds itself out on the flank with a wounded Rock combatant in tow. They make a desperate push for the shuttle co-ordinates, but one falls. The survivor helps the injured Rock aboard.

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

event.text: The staff and authorities subdue the last of the renegade students; prison transport ships are already in orbit.
Your team hunkers down in the main quad and succeeds in holding off the enemy combatants and claiming control of the institution!
The students secure the remaining staff and prepare to leave the solar system - there is only one path open to them now, that of the outlaw.

Your team comes under heavy fire. One is blinded by a flash bomb and staggers past the lip of a quarry and to their death far below; the other succeeds in joining with friendly forces and ultimately claims control of the institution!

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

event.text: The students secure the remaining staff and prepare to leave the solar system - there is only one path open to them now, that of the outlaw.

As the battle proceeds the action moves away from your team's location. During the lull they're able to secure some abandoned weapons; by the time they're done the battle is largely over and they return to ship.
Things, in the end, do not go well. The enemy succeeds in flanking your team and they're forced to retreat to the ship.
The students secure the remaining staff and prepare to leave the solar system - there is only one path open to them now, that of the outlaw.

The fight goes poorly, and your team eventually finds itself out on the flank with a wounded Rock combatant in tow. They make a desperate push for the shuttle co-ordinates, but one falls. The survivor helps the injured Rock aboard.

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

event.text: The students secure the remaining staff and prepare to leave the solar system - there is only one path open to them now, that of the outlaw.
Your team hunkers down in the main quad and succeeds in holding off the enemy combatants and claiming control of the institution!
The staff and authorities subdue the last of the renegade students; prison transport ships are already in orbit.

Your team comes under heavy fire. One is blinded by a flash bomb and staggers past the lip of a quarry and to their death far below; the other succeeds in joining with friendly forces and ultimately claims control of the institution!

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

event.text: The staff and authorities subdue the last of the renegade students; prison transport ships are already in orbit.

As the battle proceeds the action moves away from your team's location. During the lull they're able to secure some abandoned weapons; by the time they're done the battle is largely over and they return to ship.
As you hail the refugee ship, a Rock ship suddenly jumps into the system... The Rockmen accuse you of protecting heretics and give you no time to argue before the ship raises its weapons.

Your Rock crewmember admonishes the patrol for their greed. Their words get through to the opposing Rock, and his tone softens. "Ah... well..." The Rock patrolman clears his throat. "...That's not who I am. I would... I would never. Let me prove to you I am a generous man." The Rockman releases the Zoltans and gives you a small tribute.
Your Rock crewmember admonishes the patrol for their greed, but this only angers the Rockmen on the other ship. "Insolent whelp! I will not be insulted by a Rock who serves aboard an enemy ship!"
As you investigate the comet, to your surprise, a chunk of it detaches... it's a Crystal ship! "You have no right to interfere with our mission!"

Ruwen holds his hands up. "I am sorry to disturb you from stasis. The Empire has changed its foreign policy since then. In fact, this whole thing started with me, many years ago. I advise you to return to the Empire to receive new orders."

"Ruwen? It must have been many years. It looks like you changed."

"Yes, I am the ambassador to the outside world. The galaxy requires our presence once more."

The other Crystals seem mystified, but they offer you a tribute as an apology for their aggression.

choice.text: Accept the offering and report to the Astrologer.

event.text: "Incredible... we've searched so many of them back in the day and never heard of Crystals dwelling within them... and this isn't even a recent development?"

choice.text: (Dianesh) "Your empress commands you to stand down."

event.text:
"Empress Dianesh? What are you doing aboard an outsider's ship?"
                   
"The Empire is taking an active role in galactic civilization once more. Your reconnaissance is no longer required."

"...of course, my liege. Please accept this offering as an apology."

choice.text: Accept the offering and report to the Astrologer.

event.text: "Incredible... we've searched so many of them back in the day and never heard of Crystals dwelling within them... and this isn't even a recent development?"

choice.text: (Crystal Crew) Try to reason with them.

event.text: "What are you doing consorting with outsiders? You are a disgrace to the Crystal Empire!" It looks like you couldn't de-escalate the situation!
The comet seems fairly unremarkable at first glance, but once you examine beneath the surface, you find crystalline technology hidden within.
"Aha! At last, I have found what I was looking for! Oh, I suppose you can keep the actual artifacts, but the data you have acquired is very useful."
The comet is, sadly, completely unremarkable, at least as far as you are concerned. You find some trace amounts of metals to harvest, but it ultimately feels like a waste of time.
"How fascinating! You see, the composition of the Crystal suggests that the age of this was from several millennia ago! What a find! ...what, you expected more?"

At first, the crystal seems basically unremarkable. However, after scraping away some of the surface, you find a strange signal within. However, the crystal is tough. It will take very deliberate strikes to shatter the weak-points of the shell.

choice.text: (Ruwen) "This is ancient! Let me try something."

event.text: Ruwen heads down to the crystal. He presses against the surface, and completely phases into it. Moments later the crystal opens up, and Ruwen returns to your ship, allowing you to examine the cargo.

choice.text: (Dianesh) "These were all thought to be lost... Let me look at it."

event.text: Dianesh flies to the comet in a shuttle. She taps the crystal in very specific places with the side of the shuttle: it hums and echoes until the crystal opens up.

choice.text: (Heavy Weapon) Shatter the crystal with an onslaught of attacks.

event.text: You target the weakest areas with your heaviest weapons, pummeling it. The crystal is tough, but eventually it shatters open, allowing you access inside.

choice.text: Just send the Astrologer your findings.

event.text: "Oh, how interesting! ...it's a shame you could not crack the crystal open, I am sure that whatever was inside would have been of great value. Still, your contribution is appreciated."
You break it apart and take it for scrap. No one will miss it.
As you start to break it apart a Rock military ship jumps nearby. "You think you can come into our sector and just steal whatever you please?! Prepare to die, vandals!"

You're far quicker than any of the guards, and in only a couple of seconds your blaster is held directly against Stonewall's head. It's a dangerous and nerve-racking exchange, but everything goes as 'planned' and a Rock transport delivers a large supply of goods.

It was a risky move, and things don't go nearly as 'planned'. The Rock guards are quicker than anticipated and one of your crew is shot in the chest. You still manage to grab Stonewall around his massive neck and hold a blaster to his moss-covered face. As your crew lies dying on the floor, a Rock transport is called in to deliver the larger amount of supplies. Once you're satisfied, you hurry back to the ship, making sure to keep your gun pointed at Stonewall the entire way back.

choice.text: (Upg. Medbay) Provide medical assistance to your crew.

event.text: Luckily your crew is able to be treated in time. You pull away from the city, glad at the success of the mission.

choice.text: (Medical Crew) Provide medical assistance to your crew.

event.text: Luckily your crew is able to be treated in time. You pull away from the city, glad at the success of the mission.

choice.text: There's nothing we can do to save our crew.

event.text: Your crew perishes in front of you, a casualty that could have been prevented if you simply hadn't tried something so daring.

removeCrew.text: Luckily your crew is cloned, relieving you of some of your guilt.

event.text: The signal is very hard to decode. You're forced to give up or risk wasting too much time.
The signal is very hard to decode. You're forced to give up or risk wasting too much time.
The signal is difficult to decode, but you're able to break it. It appears to be the location for a pirate cache on a nearby planet!
You search for a long time, but you only end up getting lost in the nebula. This has been a large waste of time.

You find the ship emitting the signal, an emptied pirate ship. Now that you know the origins of the signal, you're able to easily decode the signal. It appears to be the location for a pirate cache on a nearby planet!
The Slugs are helpless at stopping you. You take all that you can from the platform.
The Slugs aren't interested in just letting you escape with their supplies. The station powers up its weapons and attacks!
Despite your caution, the lack of detection equipment allows debris to crash into your ship, damaging the hull. You salvage what you can and prepare to jump before anything worse happens.

Within the ship graveyard you find one ship that seems relatively untouched. On board you find an unconscious passenger, and take them back to the ship. Once awake they offer to join your crew in thanks.

While the crew is off the ship searching through the wrecks, two hulls crash into each other breaking the crew's tethers. You have no time to react as someone is knocked away, floating helplessly into the gaseous clouds...

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, your crewmember was close enough to the ship for the Clone Bay to revive them.

event.text: Among the junk and scrap you find a salvageable drone schematic. You decide to quit while ahead and prepare to jump with your recent find.
Most of the debris is hardly even usable as scrap. However, you eventually find an intact weapon that can be mounted on your ship.

Within the ship graveyard you find one ship that seems relatively untouched. On board you find an unconscious passenger and take him back to the ship. Once awake they offer to join your crew in thanks.
Among the junk and scrap you find a salvageable drone schematic. You decide to quit while ahead and prepare to jump with your recent find.
Most of the debris is hardly even usable as scrap. However, you eventually find an intact weapon that can be mounted on your ship.
Your pilot carefully explores the wrecks, but the storm has taken its toll. Any crew are long-since dead and the floating debris has been scorched beyond repair.
The two ships seem to have destroyed each other. This is fortunate for you, because now you have two wrecks to salvage.
A Mantis vessel stands victorious over its rival, a fellow Mantis ship. They aren't one to pass up another fight, so they immediately lock onto you and attack.
A Pirate vessel stands victorious over its rival, a Civilian ship. They aren't one to pass up another fight, so they immediately lock onto you and attack.
A Slug vessel stands victorious over its rival, a Rock ship. They aren't one to pass up another fight, so they immediately lock onto you and attack.
A Ghost vessel stands victorious over its rival, a Slug ship. They aren't one to pass up another fight, so they immediately lock onto you and attack.
A Duskbringer vessel stands victorious over its rival, a Zoltan ship. They aren't one to pass up another fight, so they immediately lock onto you and attack.

Luckily space whales are so large that you can easily explore inside them. The contents of their stomach are... concerning. Littered with debris and dead ships, you hastily collect some parts and leave before you can meet the same fate.

Luckily space whales are so large that you can easily explore inside them. It seems another ship is exploring this whale, or maybe they're just a victim of the whale's immense appetite, but a nasty pirate ship locks onto you and attacks!
The mines were active after all! They lock onto your hull and move in, causing damage to your ship's integrity. You pull out before more damage can be done.
Luckily the mines are inactive and the Trapper remains unresponsive. You salvage some missiles and a Mine Launcher.
It appears you were mistaken about the Trapper being empty. The ship activates as you move in, and seeing your intentions as hostile they attack!
You immediately slip further into the clouds, but not quickly enough. The Rebel catches sight of you and moves in to engage!
You arm the weapons and prepare to fight the Rebel ship.

choice.text: (Upg. Engines) Fully power the engines to out-run them.

event.text: Your powerful engines allow you to out-distance the ship and eventually lose it within the nebula.
You power down non-essential systems and slip into the cloud. The ship never noticed you.
The ship spots you and gives chase. After some quick maneuvering you were able to lose your pursuers in the clouds. You expect they warned the fleet of your position, however.
You successfully sneak by the ship and access the station undetected.
You try to sneak past the automated ship but it quickly turns and attacks!
You successfully hack into the station and sever the connection to the automated ship. You access the station undetected.
You send a drone to hack the station but the automated ship notices and turns to attack!
Your weapon successfully disables the connection to the automated ship. You access the station undetected.
You try to to hack the station with your weapon but the automated ship notices and turns to attack!
Your search is hopeless. Your sensors can't pick up anything in the nebula.
While searching fruitlessly through the nebula, you stumble upon the Rebel ship which the Federation loyalists were likely hiding from. You prepare for a fight.
You get lucky and find them floating not too deep into the nebula. Thrilled to be found by friendlies, they come on board and abandon their wrecked ship.

Your local radar flickers, periodically showing signs of a large object in the clouds nearby. However it's enough to get coordinates and you find the ship... an empty hull, long since stripped of functioning components.
You follow the faint signatures and find them floating not too far away into the nebula. Thrilled to be found by friendlies, they come on board and abandon their wrecked ship.
You follow their vapour trails and surf onto their six o'clock, weapons hot.
Without sensors you can't maintain a lock for long. The Rebels slip away.
You get disoriented in the nebula and lose your bearings completely. It takes some time to get back to the beacon. It's likely the fleet has had time to advance closer to your position.

You dock with the civilians and board their ship to find the interior thick with nebulous gases. You rush to find any survivors, but it appears most did not make it. All of your crew manage to make their way back to the ship without further casualties.

The interior of the civilian ship is thick with nebulous gases, sucked into their ship by the faulty life support system. There doesn't appear to be any survivors, and when your crew arrive back to the ship one of them is missing. It's presumable that they were lost in the clouds and suffocated.

removeCrew.text: Fortunately, regardless of whether your suspicions were correct, your crew is already in the process of being revived by the Clone Bay.

event.text: It seems a malfunction in the life support system, accompanied by a breach in the hull, led to the nebulous gases being sucked into the civilian vessel. Most of the crew appear to have already suffocated, but one survivor remains.
The ship explains that they are a military vessel for the Federation. Their partner, a fellow military vessel, got lost in the nebula and hasn't returned. They request that you track down the ship.
It turns out the ship isn't far from your current location, but they're in trouble. They're under attack from a Rebel ship!

The ship appears to be an Engi escort. "Primary mission: protect high importance Zoltan shuttle. Failure. Ship is lost in nebula. Sensors non-functional. We offer scrap in return for favor - tracking lost ship."
It turns out the ship isn't far from your current location, but they're in trouble. A mercenary ship looking to take out the Zoltan has locked onto the shuttle and is barreling towards them!

The ship turns out to be a Federation science vessel. They were transporting a Federation Auto-Drone through this sector but the AI went faulty and the ship got lost in the nebula. They ask that you track it down.
It turns out the ship isn't far from your current location, but the Auto-ship is under attack by a Rebel Engineer looking to steal the tech for themselves!
You successfully lose the ship in the storm.
Despite your advanced engines you are unable to shake them; you turn and prepare for a fight.
The civilians are extremely grateful for your help. After gathering all of their possessions and coming aboard, they permit you to scrap their old ship.
The civilians are very thankful for your help. Most agree to be dropped off at the nearest station, but one of them finds themselves longing for some change. They offer to join your crew.

As the civilians come aboard, you notice one of them is carrying an unusually large weapon concealed by their robes. It may just be for self-defense, and calling them out as a threat could cause problems.

You point out the weapon, quickly drawing your blaster before they can do the same. The civilians panic, and they try to explain that the one in the robe is their bodyguard. You apologize but your rash actions have done their damage. The civilians reluctantly go into the cargo bay and refuse to speak to any of your crew until you drop them off at a nearby station, where they briefly thank you and leave as fast as possible.

You draw your laser and stare down the robed "civilian". The rest of the civilians and your crew do the same, and now you find yourself in a rather precarious situation. "Well then captain, I have to applaud you for figuring out this was a ruse. Give us some scrap and we'll be on our way. Otherwise, it's lights out for all-" You cut him off with a shot to the head. Chaos ensues and you prepare to defend the ship from the other pirates.
Luckily, nothing seems to come of it. You drop off the civilians at the nearest station, where they thank and pay you.

You've helped all of the civilians into the cargo-bay and begun to head back to the bridge when you hear the unmistakable sound of a teleporter. You run back to catch several of the "civilians" teleporting away with the contents of your storage. The remaining pirates prepare to fight.
The civilians are extremely grateful for your help. After gathering all of their possessions and coming aboard, they permit you to scrap their old ship.
The civilians are very thankful for your help. Most agree to be dropped off at the nearest station, but one of them finds themselves longing for some change. They offer to join your crew.

The civilians begin to move aboard, but your security notices several of the civilians trying to smuggle weapons onboard. They drop their guns immediately and surrender. Seems this was an elaborate pirate trap! Considering they had no problem trying to rob you, you don't feel guilty at all extorting them for their stuff.
You try to convince the refugees to leave. The outcast escort captain sighs. "I can see we are outnumbered. So be it. We will move along."
You try to convince the refugees to leave. The outcast escort glares. "We have come so far, and traveled so long. We aren't moving. You can attack us or you can leave. Do what you will."
The Outcast responds to your hostile actions by powering weapons.
You leave the scene behind. The situation is still unresolved, but seems to be nonviolent for now.

The captain of the Militia patrol sputters. "Me? A bigot? I'm just... Look I'm.... I'm trying to represent the interests of... I'm just... Whatever! Stay, then. Watch as things go badly, and I will still be here to say I told you so!"
The captain of the Militia patrol scoffs. "You Federation types. You don't get it. You think everything is solved by a little hand holding. Get out of here, this doesn't concern you."
You've heard enough. This Militia ship seems unreasonable. They respond in kind.
You leave the scene behind. The situation is still unresolved, but seems to be nonviolent for now.
The captain of the Militia patrol growls at you. "I'm sick of the Federation always acting so high and mighty. Time to knock you down a peg!"
"Whoa whoa, calm down man! I didn't mean nothing by it, we're all friends here! See, friends!" The Union ship tosses a weapon out of the hold and keeps its distance from you.
"Oh you wanna go? You wanna go? I can take you!" The Union ship preempts you by attacking first!
"Well uh... you know uh... I would totally kick your ass, but I have too much work to do. So there." The ship quickly disengages.

You send the Lanius a very clear message trying to discern their situation. By sheer luck, you manage to find a pattern in their screeches. The communication you form is very rudimentary - you send an image, they send dings or screeches to determine whether you're hot or cold. Essentially, they seem to be stuck, and they only want to trade, because they are hungry.
You hail the station. The station's comm officer seems relieved. "You think so? Well, let's get out there and fix it then." In short order, the station and Lanius are separated.

You send the Lanius message after message trying to evoke a meaningful response. The response you get back range from screeches to dings. As much as you try, neither of you are able to get through to each other, although the Lanius doesn't seem to make any aggressive moves.

choice.text: Tell the station you can't determine the problem.

event.text: "So that's it then? We're just stuck like this...? I guess we'll just have to figure it out on our own..."
You hail the Lanius. You try to probe them for what's going on. However, after several messages of no success, something you say suddenly makes them shift their behavior - they become aggressive!
You're pretty certain the Ghosts spot you multiple times, but never once do they try and stop you. Maybe they're just very understanding?
It doesn't take long for the Ghosts to spot you... one ship flies out to match you. Looks like it was an elite, but now it's in the hands of the Ghosts!

"Huh? But I have already been there! I've laid sight on all that system has to offer, but there is no acid nebula to be seen. Had you simply said no there would have been no harm, but lying to me? Unforgivable, I shall not live with such an insult going unmatched!"
"Ooooh, ooooh! I must head there at once! Thank you for your assistance, oh seer of those things which beg of being seen!"
"Your donations are most generous, but they will not be enough to accommodate everyone. This vessel will live another day, but I must seek somewhere new to continue my travels. You will do."
"Your donations are most generous, but they will not be enough to accommodate everyone. This vessel will live another day, but I must seek somewhere new to continue my travels. You will do."
"Your donations are most generous, but they will not be enough to accommodate everyone. This vessel will live another day, but I must seek somewhere new to continue my travels. You will do."
"You... you want to BUY one of thessse freaksss? Well, can't argue with sssome ssscrap."
"You... you want to BUY one of thessse freaksss? Well, can't argue with sssome ssscrap."
"You... you want to BUY one of thessse freaksss? Well, can't argue with sssome ssscrap."
"You... you want to BUY one of thessse freaksss? Well, can't argue with sssome ssscrap."
During the salvage mission, the ship unexpectedly flickers to life! The Ghost crew stir to animation, awoken by your attempts at tearing apart their newly-earned home.
The ship remains lifeless as you break down the hull.
You intend to ignore the wreck, but it appears the Ghosts aboard intend to fight you! The ship stirs to life and its weapons come online, leaving you with only one choice; to fight.
If there are Ghosts aboard, you have no interest in waking them. You decide to spend your time on something else.
The Rockman begins shrieking and smashes the camera. It doesn't take long until their weapons are live and the insane Rock crew is ready to destroy you.
The captain shrivels over in fear and begs you not to eat their stomachs. You don't believe the Ghosts are carnivorous at all, but the Rockmen clearly don't know that.
The Rockman begins to cry. "No no no no, no, NO!" He slams his fist on the table in front of him and orders his psychotic crew to pull themselves together and attack.
"Oh thank you, thank you thank you thank you..." The captain crumples into a crying heap, mumbling thank you's and other incoherent ramblings. You leave them be.

"You... You are not Ghosts? I do not believe it! We have encountered only hell-spawn here, so it is clear that only demons inhabit this sector!" You don't bother explaining that by their logic they would be Ghosts as well, because their weapons are live.
"Good good good, good... good. You be careful, the Ghosts, they're everywhere!" The Rockman bursts in a fit of psychotic laughter and ends the call. You put some distance between your two ships.

You wait and watch the Ghosts as they look over every inch of your system. Though they have no visible tools, you wonder if they're taking measurements. One of the Ghosts tinkers with the mechanism in the system, then just as suddenly as they appeared the Ghosts walk out the door and disappear. You don't know what they've done, but it almost seems as if your engines are running at higher capacity than before.

You wait and watch the Ghosts as they look over every inch of your system. Suddenly, in a violent motion, one of the Ghosts tears off a metal covering on the Multiverse drive casing, resulting in a violent explosion! You don't wait any longer and order the crew to attack.

You wait and watch the Ghosts as they look over every inch of your system. Though they have no visible tools, you wonder if they're taking measurements. One of the Ghosts tinkers with the mechanism in the system, then just as suddenly as they appeared the Ghosts walk out the door and disappear. You don't know what they've done, but it almost seems as if your engines are running at higher capacity than before. Seems you didn't need the Mind Control after all.

You wait and watch the Ghosts as they look over every inch of your system. Suddenly, one of the Ghosts looks like they're moving to tear off an important part of the Multiverse Drive casing, but fortunately you're able to engage the Mind Control just before they succeed. You're even able to get them to take out another of the Ghosts, but you'll still have to fight the rest off.

beaconType.unvisitedTooltip: You were asked to escort an unprepared vessel to these coordinates.

event.text: You arrive at your destination, but a Ghost ship is already here. You signal for the civilians to stand back while you eliminate the threat.
The Rebel is grateful for you sparing them, despite it meaning they must betray their original cause.

The Rebel puts on a facade of gratitude, which is shattered quickly when they pull out a laser and blast one of your crew! They shout "Rebellion forever!" before being shot in return. You drag the lifeless body to the airlock and send it into the endless vacuum of space.

removeCrew.text: Luckily, your killed crewmember is already undergoing the cloning process.

event.text: The Rebel is grateful for you sparing them, despite it meaning they must betray their original cause. Looks like we won't need the mind control after all.

The Rebel puts on a facade of gratitude, which is shattered quickly when they pull out a laser and try to shoot! Luckily, the mind control stops them and they drop to the floor. You hurry to drag them out the airlock.

At first uncertain whether it's a trick, once the Rebel is convinced you aren't going to stab them in the back, they offer you a small portion of what they salvaged themselves as thanks. It seems not every Rebel has a cold heart.

At first uncertain whether it's a trick, once the Rebel is convinced you aren't going to stab them in the back, they offer you a small portion of what they salvaged themselves as thanks. It seems not every Rebel has a cold heart.

The Rebel doesn't make your decision easy, as they continue to berate you from the cargo bay until you've released them. It's almost certain they'll betray you, but you aren't going to be a murderer when you have a choice.

It appears the slaves did not survive the fighting. You find their burnt bodies in the hold, but before you strip the ship you hear faint noises in the walls. You break off a latch and a slave falls out of a hidden compartment, coughing. Once recomposed the slave offers to join your crew.
You scan the ship and detect no life signs. It appears the slaves died in the fight. You strip the ship and prepare to jump.
You open the cargo bay to find an Engi slave. Now freed, they give you their equivalent of a thank you. You offer them a place on your ship, which they accept.
You open the cargo bay to find a Mantis survivor, who attacks you in rage! The intruder is subdued, but left some damage.
The Leech ship slinks away like a wounded animal without another word.
The Leeches seem surprised but grateful and timidly offer a bit of their cargo.
Looks like the Leeches won't be spared that easily. They continue to press on, even reactivating their weapons just to keep you in the fight.
The Leeches are surprised but grateful. One wounded soldier offers himself up to work aboard your ship, likely as an escape from his services to the Republic.
Looks like the salvage was as you expected. You scoop it up and bring it aboard the ship.
Your crew bring aboard the salvage, noting how light it is. Once aboard, the scrap suddenly changes shape, turning into a band of angry Morphs who attack!

You disarm the weapons, hoping the Morphs will do the same. They do in fact turn their weapons offline as well, though whether they're doing that because you understood correctly or they think you're surrendering instead is up to debate. Not long after, a small Morph finds its way onto the ship, but they seem friendly and want to stay.
You disarm the weapons, hoping the Morphs will do the same. Instead, a group of angry blobs bust their way into your ship and the fight continues!
You find a small cache of supplies that were surely left for any loyal Federation ships in trouble. You take all that you need, leaving some for others to find.
As you approach the signal you receive a message on a Rebel channel, "I knew we'd catch some Federation fish with this signal. Prepare to be boarded, scum!"

None of your attempts to communicate seem to work: they just stare at you silently. As you prepare to leave, one of the creatures canters forward and forcefully nudges you away from the ship. He seems to want you to follow him. Eventually, they guide you to an old Engi ship's crash site. Inside you are able to find and reactivate an Engi!
You try to communicate in every possible way you can but the equinoids just stand there, silently judging you with their large, expressionless eyes. You prepare to leave.

You drop your Equinoid off on the planet, and it eventually mingles with the rest of the herd. When it returns to you after cantering for a while, another Equinoid is accompanying it. Seems it just found a mate by pure chance.

You drop your Equinoid off on the planet, and it eventually mingles with the rest of the herd.  After an uneventful while, you eventually call it back. You spend some time pondering what you expected to happen before eventually setting off.

Sensors show scattered signs of life although most of the crew are deceased. However the health signatures of the living indicate they are violent and unstable. You decide it's better to move on than risk engaging the remaining crew.

There are no life signs detected on the ship although there appears to be a number of deceased crew. There does not appear to be any airborn contagions so your crew quickly salvages what they can before moving on. You can only wonder what befell the station.
Inside there are signs of a great struggle; scientists lie dead where they fell, brutally dismembered. You grab a few research drone parts lying on a desk near the door and leave quickly.

You dock with the station and see a frantic person banging on the airlock door. Once inside your ship, he drops to the floor saying, "My... friends... They've gone insane... They're coming!" You hand him a blaster and turn to see a number of people charging toward the ship.

choice.text: (Adv. Medbay) Have the Advanced Medbay analyze their condition.

event.text: You hold them off while retreating into the Med-bay. Its advanced systems determine that an alien neurotoxin is the cause of their frenzy. It synthesizes an antidote and releases it into the room. After a time, the scientists recover. One offers their services as thanks for saving them.

As you explore the base, crazed screams are heard. Your team retreats back to your ship with a number of armed scientists in pursuit. One of your team starts to cough and falls in a spasm onto the floor.

choice.text: Drag him back to the ship and prepare for a fight.

event.text: As you get back on board, your injured friend rises up and starts to attack you, screaming. Caught off-guard, your remaining crew fall back as the other scientists fight their way onto the ship.

choice.text: (Teleporter) Use your Teleporter to retrieve your crew.

event.text: You beam your away team back to the ship and disengage from the station. Although the ship is safe, the infected crewmember quickly becomes frenzied and attacks.

choice.text: (Upg. Medbay) Drag him back to the Medbay.

event.text: You hold him down and the Medbay is able to stop whatever neurotoxin was on the ship from fully infecting your crew. Once he recovers, you prepare to fight off the scientists, who are beyond help.

choice.text: (Adv. Medbay) Have the Advanced Medbay analyze their condition.

event.text: You hold them off while retreating into the Med-bay. Its advanced systems determine that an alien neurotoxin is driving your crewmember insane. It synthesizes an antidote and releases it into the ship. After a time, the frenzied scientists recover and one offers to help out as thanks for saving them.

You send your drone to explore the station. What you find is disconcerting... It appears that something has caused the scientists and guards to tear each other to pieces. You abandon the drone on the station for fear that it is contagious.

Once on board the station, your drone is immediately beset by frenzied scientists and guards. It eventually gets torn apart by the mob but it has bought you enough time to disengage from the station and escape into empty space.

The cameras mounted to your drone show a chaotic scene. No people are to be found but the remnants of a recent battle onboard the ship are obvious. You instruct the drone to retrieve some useful materials before leaving.
All around you is the stench of death and decay. The life sign readings must have been malfunctioning because you really doubt anything could be alive in here. You quickly return to the ship.

Human corpses are scattered across the station. You find the source of the signal, a lone survivor that locked themselves in a storage closet. You quickly retreat with them in tow back to the ship, and hope they can recover enough to be of some use.

All around you is the stench of death and decay. Suddenly, one of your crew bends over and starts retching violently. Some sort of disease must have wiped out this station. You pull back to the ship, but it looks like your crewmember is not going to make it.
Your crewmember insists you leave them behind, not wanting to endanger the rest of the crew. Knowing the truth of this, you hurry back to the ship.

removeCrew.text: You stop your crew's clone from forming, knowing that the disease would follow into his next life.

choice.text: (Upg. Medbay) Try to cure the disease.

event.text: Your advanced medical suite is able to isolate the cause of the problem and administer an antidote. That was a close one.
You make the exchange and their team comes on board to try to improve your reactor.
You make the exchange and their team comes on board to try to improve your reactor.
You make the exchange and their team comes on board to try to improve your reactor.
A brief exploration yields nothing of interest.
Scans reveal a number of asteroids with useful compositions. You extract some fuel.
You discover the remains of ship embedded into an asteroid. It still has some functional missiles.
You happen upon an abandoned mining site. A few mining drones were left behind and could be repurposed.
The asteroid field proved more dangerous than expected. Some asteroids managed to get through your ship's defenses.
A pirate ship hiding behind one of the larger asteroids attacks you!
You decline and end comms with the station.
You prepare for combat.
A strange vessel approaches. A digital message appears on your view-screen: "This is an automated merchant. Refill this vessel with fuel and it will supply you with drones."
You decline and end comms.
You prepare for combat.
You arrive in the sector and are greeted by a science vessel waiting by the beacon. They hail you, "We find ourselves low on fuel and have a proposition."
You decline and end comms.
You attack the Zoltan ship.
Up close it's easier to tell that the ship was once an Engi vessel. One of their drones is still in good enough condition that you can scan it for a functional schematic.
It turns out most of the supplies onboard were destroyed, the fuel having burned up and the ammunition having exploded. You scrap off what little scrap you can from the exterior.
Miraculously, you find a living Rockman onboard, who survived the solar flares and kept the life support functional long enough to receive help. You bring them onboard your ship.
There is far less worth salvaging on the wreck than expected.
You jump when the ship powers up, revealing itself to be a still functional Rock vessel. They're furious you tried to scrap their ship while they were still aboard, and attack.
Up close it's easier to tell that the ship was once an Engi vessel. One of their drones is still in good enough condition that you can scan it for a functional schematic.
It turns out most of the supplies onboard were destroyed, the fuel having burned up and the ammunition having exploded. You scrap off what little scrap you can from the exterior.
Miraculously, you find a living Rockman onboard, who survived the solar flares and kept the life support functional long enough to receive help. You bring them onboard your ship.
There is far less worth salvaging on the wreck than expected.
You jump when the ship powers up, revealing itself to be a still functional Rock vessel. They're furious you tried to scrap their ship while they were still aboard, and attack.
Luckily you're able to get away from the wreckage before a solar flare can hit your ship. Now all you must do is wait for the FTL drive to charge.
Unfortunately, your salvage mission took too long, and a brutal solar flare hits your ship.
They thank you for your generosity and offer some scrap in exchange.
They thank you and offer to have their engineers repair some of your ship's hull.
They thank you and offer to have their engineers try to upgrade your reactor.
"Wow. This will help our efforts considerably. Let me see what I can scrounge up to offer you." They deliver some scrap and have their team try to repair part of your hull.
"Wow. This will help our efforts considerably." They offer to have their engineers fix up your ship and upgrade your reactor.
"Wow. This will help our efforts considerably. What could I offer for your troubles..." After some time they deliver a ship Augment for installation on your ship.
They thank you for your generosity and offer some scrap in exchange.
They thank you and offer to have their engineers repair some of your ship's hull.
They thank you and offer to have their engineers try to upgrade your reactor.
